questions.text: Most Common source of Liver abscess is :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common source of liver abscesses today is infection from the biliary tract
  • Conditions such as ascending cholangitis, biliary obstruction, and biliary-enteric anastomoses facilitate the spread of bacteria into the liver via the intrahepatic bile ducts
  • Although ruptured appendicitis used to be a common cause, it has now been surpassed by biliary tract diseasedue to advances in diagnosis and treatment

Explanation of other options:

Direct extension (Option A): Refers to infection spreading from adjacent structures (e.g., perforated viscus), which is less common than biliary spread.

Portal vein (Option B): Can transmit infection from intra-abdominal sources, especially in appendicitis or diverticulitis, but is now less frequent due to early intervention.

Cryptogenic (Option D): Accounts for a minority of liver abscesses where no clear source is identified, but it is not the most common cause.

Key Takeaways:

  • Biliary tract infections are the leading source of pyogenic liver abscesses
  • Portal vein and direct spread are less frequent due to early control of intra-abdominal infections
  • Cryptogenic abscesses lack an identifiable cause but are uncommon

choices.text: HB concentration < 10 g/dL and BUN > 28 mg/dL - Independent predictors of mortality in patients found to have pyogenic liver abscess.
In patients with pyogenic liver abscess, blood cultures are usually negative.
Patients with amoebic liver abscess classically present with a single large abscess in the right lobe of the liver.
Treatment duration for Pyogenic liver abscesses usually is 10 days.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding liver abscess.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The treatment duration for pyogenic liver abscess is typically longer than 10 days
  • Initial therapy involves 2 to 3 weeks of intravenous antibiotics, followed by oral antibiotics to complete a total course of 4 to 6 weeks
  • Shorter durations may lead to incomplete resolution or relapse, especially in multiloculated abscesses or immunocompromised patients

Explanation of other options:

HB concentration < 10 g/dL and BUN > 28 mg/dL  Independent predictors of mortality (Option A): These are recognized independent predictors of mortality in patients with pyogenic liver abscess, indicating severe systemic illness.

In patients with pyogenic liver abscess, blood cultures are usually negative (Option B): True, Blood cultures are often negative, although aspirated pus cultures are more reliable for identifying pathogens.

Patients with amoebic liver abscess classically present with a single large abscess in the right lobe (Option C): Correct, This is a typical presentation for amoebic liver abscess, especially in young men in endemic areas.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pyogenic liver abscesses require prolonged treatment: IV antibiotics followed by oral therapy totaling 4–6 weeks
  • Low hemoglobin and high BUN are mortality predictors
  • Blood cultures may be negative, requiring aspiration for diagnosis

questions.text: The commonest cause of acute bacterial meningitis in adults?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of acute bacterial meningitis in adults over 20 years of age
  • It accounts for nearly 50% of reported adult meningitis cases
  • Risk factors for pneumococcal meningitis include:
    • Pneumococcal pneumonia
    • Otitis media, sinusitis
    • Alcoholism, diabetes mellitus
    • Splenectomy, complement deficiency, and basilar skull fractures with CSF leak

Common Organisms in Meningitis by Age Group:

Explanation of other options:

meningitidis (Option A): More common in adolescents and young adults, but not the leading cause in adults over 20 years.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): Can cause nosocomial or post-neurosurgical meningitis, but is not a common cause of spontaneous community-acquired meningitis.

Haemophilus spp (Option C): Previously a leading cause in children, but incidence has drastically declined due to Hib vaccination.

Key Takeaways:

  • pneumoniae is the most common cause of adult bacterial meningitis
  • Risk factors include respiratory tract infections, immunodeficiency, and CSF leak
  • meningitidis is common in younger individuals, but not adults >20 years

questions.text:
A 25-year-old primary school teacher presents to a local central hospital reported to be well at 8 a.m., confused by 10 a.m, and drowsy at 11 a.m.on examination she was restless and agitated Glasgow Coma Scale 10/15, Pupil size were normal and reactive to light, the neck was stiff and there was no rash, Planter responses were down-going, Kernig's sign was positive, Chest and abdominal examinations were unremarkable,vitals were temperature 40°C, pulse 125 bpm, blood pressure 125/68 oxygen saturation 93% on room air.On CSF analysis :
Appearance : Turbid
Cells : 5000 cells/mm3 (60% Neutrophils)
Proteins : 320 mg/dL
Sugar : 18 mg/dl
What will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with acute onset of altered mental status, fever, neck stiffness, and positive Kernig’s sign, all classic features of acute bacterial meningitis
  • The CSF profile is strongly suggestive of bacterial etiology:
    • Turbid appearance
    • High WBC count (5000 cells/mm³) with neutrophil predominance
    • Low CSF glucose (18 mg/dL)
    • Very high protein (320 mg/dL)
  • These findings meet diagnostic criteria for acute bacterial meningitis, characterized by:
    • Opening pressure >180 mmHâ‚‚O
    • Neutrophilic pleocytosis
    • CSF glucose <40 mg/dL or CSF/serum glucose ratio <0.4
    • Protein >45 mg/dL

Explanation of other options:

Cryptococcal Meningitis (Option B): Typically seen in immunocompromised hosts; CSF shows mononuclear predominance, mildly elevated protein, and normal/low glucose, but not this level of neutrophilic pleocytosis.

TB Meningitis (Option C): Shows lymphocytic predominance, very high protein, and low glucose, but typically presents subacutely, not with sudden deterioration.

Viral Meningitis (Option D): CSF findings include lymphocytic predominance, normal or mildly elevated protein, and normal glucose; this patient's profile is too inflammatory for a viral cause.

Key Takeaways:

  • Acute bacterial meningitis presents with sudden neurologic decline and classic triad: fever, neck stiffness, altered mental status
  • CSF findings: neutrophilic pleocytosis, low glucose, high protein
  • Other meningitis types usually show lymphocyte predominance

choices.text: One of the most common bacterial causes of meningitis in both adults and children.
The drug of choice in the Penicillin resistant case is Vancomycin + Ceftriaxone.
Duration of therapy should be 2 weeks.
CSF sterilization occurs after completion of appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: False about Pneumococcal Meningitis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In pneumococcal meningitis, CSF sterilization should occur within 24–36 hours of initiating appropriate antimicrobial therapy, not after completion
  • A repeat lumbar puncture (LP) is recommended within this window to confirm sterilization
  • Failure to sterilize CSF within 36 hours suggests possible antibiotic resistance and warrants modification of therapy

Explanation of other options:

One of the most common bacterial causes of meningitis in both adults and children (Option A): True, Streptococcus pneumoniae is a leading cause of bacterial meningitis across all age groups.

The drug of choice in the Penicillin resistant case is Vancomycin + Ceftriaxone (Option B): True,  Empiric treatment for penicillin-resistant strains includes vancomycin plus a third-generation cephalosporin(e.g., ceftriaxone or cefotaxime).

Duration of therapy should be 2 weeks (Option C): True, The recommended duration of treatment for pneumococcal meningitis is typically 14 days (2 weeks) with IV antibiotics.

Key Takeaways:

  • CSF sterilization should be confirmed within 24–36 hours, not at end of therapy
  • Failure to sterilize early may indicate resistant pneumococcus
  • Vancomycin + ceftriaxone is the empirical therapy for resistant cases

choices.text: Penicillin G 400,000 U/kg q4h for 2 weeks
Penicillin G 400,000 U/kg q4h for 1 week.

questions.text: A 21 year old pregnant woman came with a 2 year irritable child with fever and non blanching rash. On further workup, the child was diagnosed with Meningococci meningitis. How will you treat the child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In cases of meningococcal meningitis caused by penicillin-sensitive strains, the treatment of choice is Penicillin G
  • The recommended pediatric dosing is 400,000 units/kg every 4 hours, and the duration of therapy is 7 days (1 week)
  • Short-course therapy is sufficient due to the rapid bactericidal action of penicillin and the typically favorable response in meningococcal infections

Explanation of other options:

Ceftriaxone 100 mg/kg q12h for 2 weeks (Option A): Used for penicillin-resistant strains, but 2 weeks is excessive for uncomplicated meningococcal meningitis.

Ceftriaxone 4 gm/day q12h for 1 week (Option B): Adult dosing is not appropriate for a 2-year-old child, and dosing is excessive.

Penicillin G 400,000 U/kg q4h for 2 weeks (Option C): Correct drug and dose for sensitive strains, but 2 weeks exceeds the standard 7-day duration for meningococcal meningitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Penicillin G is the drug of choice for sensitive Neisseria meningitidis
  • 7-day course is adequate for uncomplicated meningococcal meningitis
  • Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime are used for resistant strains or penicillin allergy

choices.text: This is a case of definite endocarditis.
This is a case of possible endocarditis
E.coli is never a cause of endocarditis.

questions.text: A 65 year old Female with RHD, MS, MR and AF on Amiodarone and warfarin. She had fever on and off for 2 months, had several dental extractions during this period. 2 of 3 blood cultures done 24 hrs apart showed E .coli. PT/INR was 8. TE - 10 mm vegetation with independent motility was seen. Urine showed pyuria. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient meets the modified Duke criteria for definite infective endocarditis (IE):
    • One major criterion: Echocardiographic evidence of valvular vegetation (10 mm, independently mobile)
    • Three minor criteria:
      • Predisposing heart condition (RHD with MS and MR)
      • Fever (on and off for 2 months)
      • Positive blood culture not meeting major criteria (E. coli is not a typical IE organism, but 2/3 cultures were positive)
  • According to the Duke criteria, a diagnosis of definite IE requires either:
    • 2 major criteria
    • 1 major + 3 minor criteria
    • 5 minor criteria
  • Hence, this case fits 1 major + 3 minor → Definite IE

Explanation of other options:

This is a case of possible endocarditis (Option B):
Does not apply, criteria for definite endocarditis are fulfilled.

coli is never a cause of endocarditis (Option C):
Incorrect, While not a typical cause, E. coli can cause endocarditis, especially in patients with prosthetic valves or urosepsis.

None of the above (Option D):
Incorrect, Criteria for definite endocarditis are clearly met.

Diagnostic Criteria for Infective Endocarditis – Modified Duke Criteria

Key Takeaways:

Modified Duke criteria is the standard diagnostic tool for infective endocarditis

  • Echocardiographic vegetation + 3 minor findings confirms definite IE
  • coli is uncommon, but possible as an etiologic agent

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common sexually transmitted pathogen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) is the most common sexually transmitted pathogen worldwide and in the United States
  • A landmark study showed that nearly 60% of initially HPV-negative, sexually active women acquired infection within 5 years
  • HPV transmission is highly efficient, often occurring soon after sexual debut
  • Many infections are asymptomatic and self-limited, but high-risk HPV strains are associated with cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal cancers

Explanation of other options:

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option A): A common protozoal STI, but significantly less prevalent than HPV.

Human immunodeficiency virus (Option B): Less common than HPV; has serious long-term consequences, but not the most frequent STI.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option C): A frequent cause of urethritis and cervicitis, but less common than HPV, particularly in asymptomatic carriers.

Key Takeaways:

  • HPV is the most common STI, often acquired early in sexual activity
  • Infection may be asymptomatic but carries oncogenic potential
  • Vaccination offers strong protection against high-risk strains

questions.text: Organisms commonly causing Non gonococcal urethritis in males are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is a common STI in males not caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • The major causative organisms include:
    • Chlamydia trachomatis – responsible for 30–40% of NGU cases
    • Mycoplasma genitalium – increasingly recognized as a cause, particularly in Chlamydia-negative NGU
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum – also implicated in some cases
  • However, Ureaplasma parvum is not considered a true pathogen in NGU; it is often found in the urogenital tract as a commensal without pathogenic significance

Explanation of other options:

Chlamydia trachomatis (Option A): Most common identifiable cause of NGU.

Mycoplasma genitalium (Option B): Emerging recognized cause, especially in persistent or recurrent NGU.

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect,  U. parvum is not a recognized cause of NGU, making Option C the exception.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ureaplasma parvum is not implicated in non-gonococcal urethritis
  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the leading cause
  • genitalium is important in persistent or Chlamydia-negative cases

choices.text: It does not increase the risk of HIV
Treatment of male partners reduces recurrence.
Pregnant women should be routinely screened for bacterial vaginosis.
Atopobium vagina is associated with recurrence.

questions.text: True about bacterial vaginosis:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atopobium vaginae is frequently identified in women with recurrent bacterial vaginosis (BV) and contributes to biofilm formation that protects Gardnerella vaginalis and other anaerobes from treatment
  • BV is associated with a polymicrobial imbalance in vaginal flora and is characterized by loss of lactobacilli and overgrowth of anaerobic organisms including Gardnerella, Mobiluncus, and Atopobium
  • Its persistence is a key factor in relapse despite standard metronidazole therapy

Explanation of other options:

It does not increase the risk of HIV (Option A):
Incorrect — BV does increase susceptibility to HIV, C. trachomatis, and N. gonorrhoeae by disrupting mucosal immunity.

Treatment of male partners reduces recurrence (Option B):
Incorrect — Treating male partners with metronidazole has not been shown to reduce recurrence rates in women.

Pregnant women should be routinely screened for bacterial vaginosis (Option C):
Incorrect — Routine screening is not recommended, except in high-risk pregnancies (e.g., history of preterm birth).

Key Takeaways:

  • Atopobium vaginae contributes to recurrent BV due to biofilm persistence
  • BV increases STI risk including HIV
  • Routine screening in pregnancy and partner treatment are not supported

questions.text: Janeway lesion can be described best as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Janeway lesions are painless, erythematous or hemorrhagic macular lesions, typically found on the palms and soles
  • They are a classic peripheral stigmata of infective endocarditis (IE) and represent septic microemboli with microabscess formation
  • Unlike Osler nodes, which are painful and immune-complex mediated, Janeway lesions are nontender and more vascular/embolic in origin

Key Takeaways:

  • Janeway lesions = painless, hemorrhagic, palmar/plantar embolic lesions
  • Osler nodes = painful, raised, and immune complex-mediated
  • Both are signs of infective endocarditis

questions.text: What is the most common etiology of complicated UTI?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Escherichia coli is the most common cause of both uncomplicated and complicated urinary tract infections (UTIs), including catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI)
  • Despite the broader range of organisms involved in complicated UTIs, coli still accounts for the majority of cases
  • The acronym SEEK PP summarizes key uropathogens:
    • Staphylococcus saprophyticus
    • coli
    • Enterococcus
    • Klebsiella
    • Proteus
    • Pseudomonas

Explanation of other options:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option A):
Seen more in nosocomial and instrumentation-related UTIs, but less common than E. coli.

Proteus (Option C):
Known for causing struvite stones, but still secondary to E. coli.

Klebsiella (Option D):
Another common pathogen, especially in hospitalized patients, but not the most frequent.

Key Takeaways:

  • coli is the dominant pathogen in both simple and complicated UTIs
  • Complicated UTIs involve a broader spectrum, but coli still leads
  • SEEK PP helps recall common urinary pathogens

questions.text: Which of the following is not a first line therapy drug for treatment of acute uncomplicated cystitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ceftriaxone is not considered a first-line agent for the treatment of acute uncomplicated cystitis in women
  • The first-line therapies for uncomplicated cystitis, based on efficacy, safety, and resistance profiles, include:
    • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
    • Nitrofurantoin
    • Fosfomycin
    • Pivmecillinam (in some guidelines)
  • These drugs are chosen for their targeted activity against uropathogens (mainly coli) and low risk of collateral damage (e.g., resistance selection)
  • Ceftriaxone is a parenteral third-generation cephalosporin, usually reserved for complicated UTIs or pyelonephritis, not uncomplicated cystitis

Antimicrobials Used to Treat Acute Uncomplicated Cystitis:

Explanation of other options:

Fosfomycin (Option A):
First-line agent; administered as a single oral dose (3 g).

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Option B):
First-line therapy when local resistance <20%; typically used for 3 days.

Nitrofurantoin (Option C):
Commonly used first-line drug, especially in young women; given for 5–7 days.

Key Takeaways:

  • Ceftriaxone is not a first-line oral option for uncomplicated cystitis
  • Nitrofurantoin, TMP-SMX, and fosfomycin are preferred agents
  • Parenteral agents are reserved for complicated or upper tract infections

questions.text: Which of the mentioned drugs is not ideal for treatment of UTI in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin) are not recommended in pregnancy for the treatment of urinary tract infections (UTIs) due to concerns about fetal musculoskeletal toxicity seen in animal studies
  • Safer alternatives in pregnancy include:
    • Nitrofurantoin (especially after the first trimester)
    • Beta-lactams such as ampicillin and cephalosporins

Explanation of other options:

Nitrofurantoin (Option A): Generally considered safe, especially in the second and third trimesters; caution is advised near term due to risk of hemolytic anemia in G6PD-deficient neonates.

Cephalosporin (Option B): Safe in all trimesters; widely used for both uncomplicated and complicated UTIs in pregnancy.

Ampicillin (Option C): Safe and effective in pregnancy, often used for asymptomatic bacteriuria or cystitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in pregnancy due to fetal safety concerns
  • Beta-lactams and nitrofurantoin are the preferred agents for UTI in pregnancy
  • Always consider gestational age and G6PD status when choosing antibiotics

choices.text: Antibiotics with GNB and GP coverage.
Broad spectrum antibacterial and antifungal agents.

questions.text:
A 52 year old female with poor diabetes has presented with high grade fever and left flank pain for the past 3 days.
Her blood pressure : 90/50 mmHg
Hb: 9 g/dL WBC : 32,000/mm3 (88% neutrophil)
Urine microscopy: Plenty of pus cells
CT scan : Left bulky left kidney with extensive diffuse gas in the cortex and collecting system.
Which of the following will be her line of treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient presents with emphysematous pyelonephritis (EPN) — a life-threatening necrotizing infection of the kidney, most often seen in uncontrolled diabetes mellitus
  • CT findings of gas in the renal cortex and collecting system are diagnostic
  • Initial management includes:
    • Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics with gram-negative coverage (e.g., coli, Klebsiella)
    • CT-guided percutaneous drainage, especially in hemodynamically unstable patients
  • Nephrectomy is reserved for patients not improving with conservative measures

Explanation of other options:

Antibiotics + left side nephrectomy (Option A): Nephrectomy may be needed later if there's no response, but not the initial step, especially in an acutely ill, unstable patient.

Antibiotics with GNB and GP coverage (Option C): Antibiotics are necessary but not sufficient alone in EPN; source control with drainage is essential.

Broad spectrum antibacterial and antifungal agents (Option D): Fungal coverage is not routinely indicated unless the patient is severely immunocompromised or has specific fungal risk factors.

Key Takeaways:

  • Emphysematous pyelonephritis occurs in diabetics and presents with renal gas on imaging
  • Initial treatment = IV antibiotics + percutaneous drainage
  • Nephrectomy is considered if no response to conservative therapy

choices.text: Cystitis is a risk factor for recurrent cystitis and pyelonephritis
Recurrent infection leads to renal failure.
ASB is common among elderly but does not in itself increase the risk of death
Infection plays prime role for development of Chronic Interstitial Nephritis

questions.text: Which of the following is false:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • While recurrent infections such as cystitis and pyelonephritis can lead to morbidity, they do not directly cause renal failure in most cases unless there are underlying structural or functional abnormalities (e.g., obstruction, vesicoureteral reflux)
  • Renal failure is more commonly associated with chronic interstitial nephritis, which has non-infectious etiologies like:
    • Analgesic nephropathy
    • Obstructive uropathy
    • Heavy metal exposure
    • Reflux nephropathy

Explanation of other options:

Cystitis is a risk factor for recurrent cystitis and pyelonephritis (Option A): Previous infection increases susceptibility to recurrence or ascent to upper urinary tract.

ASB is common among elderly but does not in itself increase the risk of death (Option C): Asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) is prevalent in the elderly and catheterized, but treatment is not indicated unless symptomatic.

Infection plays prime role for development of Chronic Interstitial Nephritis (Option D): infection does not play a prime role, which is in line with the explanation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Recurrent infections alone rarely lead to renal failure
  • ASB is common but non-lethal in itself
  • Cystitis can predispose to recurrent infections, but other factors must be present for serious renal outcomes

choices.text: IV Metronidazole with Vancomycin by NG or by retention enema
IV Vancomycin with Metronidazole by NG or by retention enema

questions.text: In the treatment of patients with fulminant clostridium difficile associated diarrhea with no oral access, what is preferred?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In fulminant Clostridium difficile infection (CDI), especially when the patient has no oral access due to ileus or other gastrointestinal complications:
    • IV metronidazole is used for systemic treatment
    • Vancomycin is administered either via nasogastric (NG) tube or rectally (as a retention enema) to deliver the drug directly to the colon
  • This combination ensures that effective concentrations of vancomycin reach the infected colon, bypassing the impaired oral route

Recommendations for the Treatment of Clostridioides difficile Infection (CDI):

Explanation of other options:

Rifaximin 200 TDS × 10 days (Option B):
Rifaximin is used for recurrences, not for initial fulminant CDI.

IV Vancomycin with Metronidazole by NG or enema (Option C):
Incorrect — IV vancomycin does not reach the colon; it is ineffective for CDI.

Nitazoxanide 500 BD × 5 days (Option D):
Not a standard or recommended therapy for C. difficile, especially in severe or fulminant disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • In fulminant CDI with no oral access, use IV metronidazole + rectal or NG vancomycin
  • IV vancomycin is not effective for CDI because it doesn’t reach the colon
  • Fidaxomicin and FMT are reserved for recurrent or refractory cases

questions.text: Urinary antigen test is used for diagnosis of pneumonia caused by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The urinary antigen test is used for the rapid diagnosis of Legionella pneumophila, particularly serogroup 1, which accounts for the majority of community-acquired Legionnaires’ disease cases in the U.S.
  • This test is valuable because it:
    • Remains positive even after antibiotic initiation
    • Has a sensitivity of ~70% and a specificity of ~99%
  • A pneumococcal urinary antigen test is also available for Streptococcus pneumoniae, with similar sensitivity and specificity.

Explanation of other options:

Chlamydia (Option B):
Chlamydophila pneumoniae is diagnosed by PCR or serology, not by urinary antigen testing.

Mycoplasma (Option C):
Mycoplasma pneumoniae is typically detected using PCR or serologic assays; no urinary antigen test is available.

Mycobacteria (Option D):
Mycobacterium tuberculosis is diagnosed using AFB smear, culture, PCR, or GeneXpert; urinary antigen testing is not applicable.

Key Takeaways:

  • Urinary antigen testing is primarily used for Legionella pneumophila (serogroup 1)
  • It is highly specific, remains useful even post-antibiotic initiation
  • Not useful for Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, or Mycobacteria

questions.text: Secondary lung abscess is due to all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Aspiration is the most common cause of a primary lung abscess, not secondary
  • Primary lung abscesses:
    • Occur without underlying systemic or structural disease
    • Commonly follow aspiration of oropharyngeal secretions, especially in patients with altered consciousness
    • Caused predominantly by anaerobic bacteria
  • Secondary lung abscesses:
    • Arise due to underlying local or systemic conditions, such as:
    • Post-obstructive lesions (e.g., foreign body, tumor)
    • Immunocompromised states, including HIV infection
    • Chronic pulmonary conditions (e.g., bronchiectasis)

Explanation of other options:

Foreign body (Option B): Can lead to post-obstructive infection, a classic cause of secondary abscess.

HIV (Option C): Immunosuppression predisposes to necrotizing infections, making it a cause of secondary abscess.

Immunocompromised (Option D): Includes a wide range of conditions (e.g., chemotherapy, organ transplant), often associated with secondary lung abscesses due to unusual pathogens.

Key Takeaways:

Aspiration → primary lung abscess

Underlying conditions → secondary lung abscess

Causes of secondary abscess include foreign body, HIV, and immunosuppression

questions.text: Which of the following is elevated in liver abscess except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In liver abscess, the most consistent laboratory abnormality is an elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level, seen in ~70% of cases
  • AST (SGOT) and total bilirubin may also be elevated, although less consistently (in ~48% and 50% of cases, respectively)
  • SGPT (ALT) is less frequently elevated, making it the least reliable marker among the liver enzymes in liver abscess

Explanation of other options:

Alkaline phosphatase (Option A): Commonly elevated due to biliary tract involvement or inflammation; most reliable lab marker in liver abscess.

SGOT (Option B): Often elevated, reflecting hepatocellular injury, although not as specific as ALP.

Total bilirubin (Option D): May be elevated in 50% of patients, usually due to hepatic inflammation or cholestasis.

Key Takeaways:

  • ALP is the most consistently elevated enzyme in liver abscess
  • SGPT (ALT) is less frequently elevated compared to ALP, SGOT, and bilirubin
  • Always consider right upper quadrant imaging in febrile patients with liver function abnormalities

questions.text: Most common symptom of the Pertussis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In pertussis (whooping cough), the most common symptom—especially in adolescents and adults—is a persistent cough that disturbs sleep
  • Though paroxysmal cough, whooping, and post-tussive vomiting are classic features, not all patientsexperience them, particularly older children and adults
  • In these groups, the prolonged nighttime cough is often the only clue, and it can persist for weeks

Explanation of other options:

Prolonged cough (Option B):
A common feature, but not as defining or distressing as sleep disruption.

Paroxysmal cough (Option C):
Characteristic of classic pertussis, but less consistently seen in adolescents and adults.

Whooping cough (Option D):
The “whoop” is typical in young children, but not always present, especially in vaccinated individuals or adults.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sleep-disrupting cough is the most common and persistent symptom in pertussis, especially in older age groups
  • Classic signs like whoop and paroxysms may be absent in adults
  • Consider pertussis in any prolonged cough disturbing sleep

questions.text: Most specific test for C.difficile is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most specific diagnostic test for Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI) is sigmoidoscopy demonstrating pseudomembranes, which are pathognomonic of the disease
  • Although PCR and toxin assays are widely used and highly sensitive, they may yield false positives in colonized but asymptomatic individuals
  • Visualization of pseudomembranes directly correlates with active disease and is therefore considered the most specific indicator of clinically significant CDI

Explanation of other options:

Stool culture (Option A):
Very sensitive, but not specific unless followed by toxin assay to confirm toxin production.

Enzyme immunoassay for toxin A (Option C):
Rapid but has lower sensitivity and can miss cases if toxin levels are low.

PCR (Option D):
Highly sensitive, but may detect non-toxigenic strains or colonization without disease — hence, less specific than direct visualization.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sigmoidoscopy showing pseudomembranes is the most specific diagnostic tool for CDI
  • PCR and toxin assays are useful screening tools but can overdiagnose colonization
  • Always interpret test results in clinical context

questions.text: Patient is scheduled for an elective splenectomy. At least how long before the operation should pneumovax be given?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In patients undergoing elective splenectomy, Pneumovax (23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine) should be administered at least 2 weeks before surgery
  • This timing ensures adequate IgG antibody production for protection against Streptococcus pneumoniae, which poses a high risk post-splenectomy
  • If vaccination is delayed until after splenectomy, immunologic response is suboptimal, increasing the risk of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI)

Key Takeaways:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine should be given ≥2 weeks before elective splenectomy
  • Aim is to optimize immune response before loss of splenic function
  • Reduces risk of fulminant bacterial infections post-splenectomy

questions.text: Which of the following does not include bacteria that are frequently implicated in COPD exacerbations ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most common bacterial pathogens associated with acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) include:
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae
    • Haemophilus influenzae
    • Moraxella catarrhalis
  • These organisms are commonly isolated from sputum during exacerbations and are well-documented triggers
  • Staphylococcus aureus, while a significant respiratory pathogen in hospital-acquired infections and immunocompromised states, is not a typical cause of COPD exacerbations in the community setting

Key Takeaways:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is not a common pathogen in COPD exacerbations
  • Common causes include pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and M. catarrhalis
  • Bacterial etiology often guides antibiotic choices during exacerbation management

questions.text: Drug of choice for treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cephalosporins (along with ampicillin) are considered drugs of choice for treating asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) in pregnancy
  • They are safe across all trimesters, have extensive clinical use, and effectively eradicate common uropathogens like coli
  • ASB in pregnancy, if untreated, can lead to pyelonephritis, preterm labor, and low birth weight, so appropriate antibiotic therapy is essential

Explanation of other options:

Sulfonamides (Option B):
Should be avoided in first trimester (teratogenicity) and near term (risk of kernicterus in neonates).

Nitrofurantoin (Option C):
Generally safe after the first trimester, but not preferred in early pregnancy or near term; associated with hemolytic anemia in G6PD-deficient neonates.

Ciprofloxacin (Option D):
A fluoroquinolone, contraindicated in pregnancy due to adverse effects on fetal cartilage and joints.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cephalosporins and ampicillin are first-line agents for ASB in pregnancy
  • Sulfonamides, nitrofurantoin, and fluoroquinolones have trimester-specific safety concerns
  • Treatment duration is 4–7 days in pregnancy

questions.text: Which joints are most frequently involved in reactive arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Reactive arthritis is an asymmetric oligoarthritis, typically affecting the lower limbs
  • The knee joints are the most frequently involved, followed by:
    • Ankles
    • Small joints of the feet
  • It often follows genitourinary or gastrointestinal infections, and is associated with HLA-B27 positivity

Explanation of other options:

Elbows (Option B): Rarely involved in reactive arthritis; upper limb joints are less commonly affected.

Small joints of hands (Option C): More typical of rheumatoid arthritis, not reactive arthritis.

Small joints of foot (Option D): May be involved, but less frequently than knees and ankles.

Key Takeaways:

  • Knees are the most commonly affected joints in reactive arthritis
  • Pattern is typically asymmetric, lower limb predominant
  • Associated with preceding infections and HLA-B27

questions.text: What is the Most common cause of nongonococcal urethritis ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common cause of urethritis in males is N. gonorrhoea. The most common cause of Non-Gonococcal urethritis in males is Chlamydia trachomatis. The most common cause of urethritis in females is Chlamydia. Hence chlamydia is the most appropriate answer.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not an indication for Endocarditis prophylaxis before dental procedure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Endocarditis prophylaxis before dental procedures is not recommended for patients with pacemaker implants
  • According to current guidelines, prophylaxis is reserved for high-risk cardiac conditions in which bacteremia could result in serious morbidity

Indications for prophylaxis include:

  • Prosthetic cardiac valves or prosthetic material used for valve repair (Option A)
  • Previous infective endocarditis
  • Congenital heart disease (CHD):
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD (e.g., TOF, Option B)
    • Repaired CHD with prosthetic material during the first 6 months
  • Cardiac transplant recipients who develop valvulopathy

Explanation of other options:

Prosthetic aortic valve (Option A): Considered high-risk for endocarditis; prophylaxis recommended.

Unrepaired TOF (Option B): Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease is an indication for prophylaxis.

LVAD (Option C): While LVAD patients are at risk of device-related infections, dental prophylaxis is not specifically indicated unless they also meet other criteria.

Pacemaker implantation (Option D):
NOT an indication — no evidence supports endocarditis prophylaxis for routine pacemaker carriers undergoing dental procedures.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dental prophylaxis is limited to select high-risk cardiac conditions
  • Pacemakers and LVADs are not indications unless other risk factors exist
  • Focus remains on prosthetic valves, prior IE, and certain CHDs

questions.text: What is the most common agent of traveler's diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) is the most common etiologic agent of traveler’s diarrhea, responsible for 10–45% of cases
  • It produces heat-labile and heat-stable enterotoxins, leading to watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and low-grade fever
  • Transmission is typically via contaminated food or water, particularly in areas with poor sanitation infrastructure

Table: Etiologic Agents in Traveler’s Diarrhea

Explanation of other options:

Enteropathogenic E. coli (Option B):
More commonly associated with infantile diarrhea, not the main cause of traveler’s diarrhea.

Enteroinvasive E. coli (Option C):
Causes a dysentery-like illness, mimicking Shigella, but less common in travelers.

Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (Option D):
Linked with bloody diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS); not a leading cause of traveler’s diarrhea.

Key Takeaways:

  • ETEC is the most common cause of traveler’s diarrhea
  • Symptoms are typically mild to moderate watery diarrhea
  • Prevention includes safe food/water practices; treatment is often supportive ± antibiotics

questions.text: What is the most common acute UTI syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Uncomplicated cystitis is the most common acute urinary tract infection (UTI) syndrome, especially in otherwise healthy, non-pregnant women.
  • It presents with localized lower urinary tract symptoms including:
    • Dysuria
    • Frequency
    • Urgency
    • Suprapubic pain
    • Occasionally hematuria, but no fever or systemic signs.

Clinical Symptoms of Urinary Tract Infections (as shown in the image):

Explanation of other options:

Pyelonephritis (Option B):
A more severe infection involving the renal parenchyma; associated with fever, flank pain, and chills. Less common than cystitis.

Urethritis (Option C):
Often due to sexually transmitted infections like Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae; presents with dysuria, but not typically classified as the most common UTI syndrome.

Renal abscess (Option D):
A rare and complicated UTI presentation; associated with prolonged fever and systemic toxicity.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cystitis is the most frequent acute UTI presentation
  • Lacks systemic features like fever or flank pain seen in pyelonephritis
  • Recognition is important to prevent progression to upper UTI

questions.text: What is the Most common source of E. coli bacteremia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The urinary tract is the most common source of Escherichia coli bacteremia, responsible for 50–66% of all cases
  • E.coli is the leading cause of urinary tract infections (UTIs), which may progress to bacteremia, especially in the presence of:
    • Urinary obstruction
    • Catheterization
    • Anatomic abnormalities
    • Immunosuppression

Explanation of other options:

Lung (Option B): While pneumonia can cause bacteremia, E. coli is an uncommon cause of primary pulmonary infection.

Large bowel (Option C): E. coli is part of the normal gut flora, but the bowel is a less common direct source of bacteremia unless perforatedor in intra-abdominal sepsis.

Small bowel (Option D): Rare source of E. coli bacteremia unless severely disrupted (e.g., ischemia, surgery).

Key Takeaways:

  • UTI is the primary source of coli bacteremia
  • Risk increases with instrumentation, obstruction, or immunocompromised states
  • Prompt UTI management reduces bacteremia risk

questions.text: Which organism is the most common nongonococcal cause of septic arthritis in native joints?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common nongonococcal cause of septic arthritis in native joints, across all adult age groups
  • It gains entry via hematogenous spread, direct inoculation, or contiguous extension
  • Risk factors include:
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Rheumatoid arthritis
    • Recent joint injection or surgery
    • IV drug use

Explanation of other options:

Streptococcus (Option B): Can cause septic arthritis, particularly in older adults and those with comorbidities, but is less common than S. aureus

Pseudomonas (Option C): Typically associated with IV drug users or post-surgical infections; not a leading cause in native joints.

coli (Option D): Seen in elderly or immunocompromised patients but remains a less frequent isolate.

Key Takeaways:

  • aureus is the leading cause of septic arthritis in native joints
  • Gram-negative organisms and streptococci are seen more often in the elderly or immunocompromised
  • Prompt recognition and treatment are critical to prevent joint destruction
